issues.title: Public APIs Situation [ READ THIS ISSUE PLEASE ]

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

issues.body:
Hi community

This message is to clarify and make transparent the current situation of Public APIs, in addition to demonstrating the frustration of us maintainers. So read this if you find it interesting, please.

Well, I keep the Public APIs project together with other 3 developers (@pawelborkar, @marekdano and @yannbertrand) for a long time.

1 year ago, the Public APIs project was dead, with over 300 open pull requests and dozens of unresolved issues. We started work and resolved all PRs and open issues in about 2 months. Since then, more than 1000 PRs have been resolved, dozens of issues resolved, several improvements to the project and a remarkable growth. So it's clear that we've revived and improved the project.

See more at: https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/issues/1268

Over time, we had several other ideas to further improve the project for the community, but we encountered a number of problems that prevented us from executing them. Many of these issues are related to our access level in the public-apis organization/repository, as we needed to activate special features in the settings and create new repositories in the organization.

We started making attempts to communicate with people working at [APILayer](https://apilayer.com/) (current owner of the public-apis organization/project) to try to help us improve the project, but this proved extremely difficult.

I spoke with employees and ex-employees, but could not get help. I also spoke to [John Burr](https://www.linkedin.com/in/johnwburr/) (APILayer's General Manager) but he hasn't responded for many months.

I made several more attempts to communicate with [Julian Zehetmayr](https://www.linkedin.com/in/julianzehetmayr/) and [Paul Zehetmayr](https://www.linkedin.com/in/paulzehetmayr/) (co-founders and former CEOs of APILayer), but got no response. I believe they are very busy people.

See more at: https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/issues/1268#issuecomment-793154290

Just trying to communicate with APILayer to help us improve the project and failing in almost every attempt is frustrating for us maintainers. In addition to other problems caused by the apilayer-admin user, who sometimes made undue modifications that caused all our tests and project policies to be broken.

See the history of apilayer-admin: https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/commits?author=apilayer-admin

Also, we noticed that this week all of us maintainers had our access levels lowered without any communication, motivation or anything close to that. Now we don't even have access to the basic settings in the repository.

So realize how frustrating this is for us, but we're still trying because we believe it's important to the community.

We have no idea why APILayer is acting this way with us maintainers who help revive and improve the project. We just want help and collaboration so that everything works well without harming the community.

So, due to all these problems, I have indicated possible solutions to help us to APILayer representatives:

- APILayer add us as one of the owners or members of the public-apis organization with the necessary access to move forward with the project
- Or if APILayer is not interested in maintaining and helping to evolve the project (which we believe, given the whole situation), transfer it to one of us maintainers so that we can improve it. I believe that this is an adequate measure given everything I have described, and it would solve several communication problems that APILayer would not need to deal with, in addition, of course, to help an entire community to improve it all. Transferring projects is very well seen by the community, and this transfer to the right people who will maintain the project.

But again I didn't get any straight answer to that. Then notice how frustrating this is.

We greatly want APILayer's collaboration and understanding. We don't want the project to die again or be used in a way that harms the community with inappropriate additions. We just want to help.

---

@yannbertrand also wrote about the situation on his blog:
- https://dev.to/yannbertrand/public-apis-situation-4101

Other links that may be useful for more information:

- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/commits/master
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/pulse/monthly
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/graphs/commit-activity
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/graphs/code-frequency
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/graphs/contributors
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/commits?author=matheusfelipeog
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/commits?author=yannbertrand
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/commits?author=pawelborkar
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/commits?author=marekdano
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/issues/1268
- https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/issues/1932#issuecomment-989514138
- https://apilayer.com/
- https://www.linkedin.com/company/apilayer/
- https://github.com/apilayer/
- https://www.ideracorp.com/developertools/apilayer

---

If this issue is permanently deleted to hide what I've described, you can find a permanent record at:

**Wayback Machine:**
- Last capture: https://web.archive.org/web/20250401164120/https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/issues/3104
- Capture history: https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/issues/3104

**archive.today:**
- Last capture: https://archive.is/TNLYa
- Capture history: https://archive.is/https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/issues/3104

comments_data.body:
To complete the discussion you should know that they lower our maintainer access after I reverted some abusive commits. apilayer-admin tried to replace our sponsor logo to their company logo.

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5855339/158750592-f3bda99a-bc96-49c6-baf4-fbe958a4e5b2.png)

It's not the first time they're trying to link the Public APIs repos to their company despite they have never contributed nor gave help maintaining the project.

https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/commit/ab16db658dcc5a443292d2ce0325d98ad0538226 They are now pushing their own business APIs above others (breaking the alphabetically-ordered CI rule). This goes against our [contributing rule](https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

Please be careful accessing links by now as we maintainers can't assure they're not pox.
They now removed the repo maintainers list, they know what they are doing https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/commit/831ff0378fb0ba5a779e6caaa89b73766c59449e
this needs more attention. apilayer seems to commercialize this project which is not any good.
I tried to reach out on twitter https://twitter.com/mangafreak1995/status/1504411468699160578?s=21

I've mentioned about this issue in order to describe the current situation of the project to the current projects/websites that we've added to the readme and are using the public-apis project at their core. And has ask them to mention it in their website's homepage or write a blog (if possible) or a tweet regarding the current situation. As these website may have some of the traffic which can help us bring this issue in front of the community members and reach the masses so that we can make sure the project survive.
Do we want to fork this as a community? This sounds exactly like the situation to do something like this.

Apilayer took over the restcountries project, stopped support, took down the website (restcountries.eu, domain still registered to apilayer) and as far as I see never acknowledge any user feedback. @amatosg, who is still a maintainer, forked it last year (restcountries.com). https://github.com/apilayer/restcountries/issues/253
Honestly you need to fork it. There's no other option. If you truly want it to be community led the entire admin ownership needs to be distributed amongst trustworthy peers.

Forking was one of the first possible solutions we considered, but that's a difficult task now.

Public APIs are over 6 years old, 185k stars and over 250k views/month, [in addition to forks over 2 years old and over 4k stars](https://github.com/public-api-lists/public-api-lists). I believe that simply forking this will have no effect, this is extremely difficult.

Also, the difficulty increased as we were unable to correctly direct visitors from Public APIs to a new repository. We do not have access to modify the README.md to report this.

We are currently awaiting a response from the project's original creator, @toddmotto, who has attempted to contact the current owners.
Maybe just move on to focusing on a website and an API itself? The GitHub repo can remain but just shift the outward focus to putting the data in an API and website you own.

@matheusfelipeog Can you change the pull request template?

> You want to contribute? Do it here!

> Maybe just move on to focusing on a website and an API itself? The GitHub repo can remain but just shift the outward focus to putting the data in an API and website you own.

There is already an official API widely used by the community and maintained by a former collaborator to Public APIs. There are also several alternative sites that use this API's database, however having an official website was in our future plans, but unfortunately this situation ends up making everything difficult.


> @matheusfelipeog Can you change the pull request template?
> 
> > You want to contribute? Do it here!

@JoshuaBehrens This would certainly be useful, but unfortunately we no longer have an access level that allows us to make changes to the repository.

Your options are very limited at this stage. If you're being met with hostility by the admin there's not much you can do considering they own the repo. As much as you may want to hold on to the traffic and GitHub stars,  it's not clear it's of much value if the owner can basically do whatever they want with unilateral authority. 

At the end of the day it's a text file. So you should feel quite comfortable forking and moving on. Even renaming to something more interesting.

> Your options are very limited at this stage. If you're being met with hostility by the admin there's not much you can do considering they own the repo. As much as you may want to hold on to the traffic and GitHub stars, it's not clear it's of much value if the owner can basically do whatever they want with unilateral authority.
> 
> At the end of the day it's a text file. So you should feel quite comfortable forking and moving on. Even renaming to something more interesting.

I agree, fork the repo and move on. Don't worry about the stars or publicity for now. Post on reddit and Twitter.
Is it worthwhile to hit the "Block or Report" button on APILayer Admin's [profile](https://github.com/apilayer-admin)? Seems like at the very least you could try and report their behaviour as SPAM'y.

I'd definitely go with forking (or should I say, cloning to a brand new repo) and clearly stating it's the community-driven effort to keep building on the former work. You know, big visible disclaimer explaining why and how this happened.

Of course the idea is to link the new repo from the top of the README of this repo to get things up to speed (for as long as the owner will allow it). What matters is you keep building there and not here, and things will eventually flow naturally over there as time goes by and this repo gets left behind.

Open source efforts are not meant to be hindered by such behaviors, and you guys alone have the power to make it right. Thanks and keep up the good work!

Incidentally, `awesome-public-apis` isn't taken ;-)

@nitefood About informing the community at the top of the README: Unfortunately we no longer have access to modify the project files, this makes it very difficult when we want to inform the whole community what happened. Few people see the issues here :/

If you cannot modify anything then there is nothing left to do but fork and go in a new direction. This issue is here, people can see it. The repo will go stale and people will wonder where everyone is going next. You can actively promote that on dev channels. Take it from me, the stars are not as valuable as the community itself. Build a real community, start a discord, etc.

> Take it from me, the stars are not as valuable as the community itself.

Spot on. The first step is always the hardest, but from what I could gather it appears inevitable.

issues.title: Hacktoberfest 2021

labels.name: hacktoberfest
labels.description: Indicates that it is valid to participate in the hacktoberfest

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

issues.body:
Open source is changing the world – one contribution at a time.

Support open source throughout October!

Hacktoberfest encourages participation in the open source community, which grows bigger every year. Complete the 2021 challenge and earn a limited edition T-shirt.

--- ## Hacktoberfest and Public APIs Public APIs is participating in hacktoberfest 2021 and needs your help to improve it even more. Please feel free to open questions / request requests and we will be happy to review your contribution. :octocat: ## Important Before making any contribution, please read our [contribution guide](https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) to help you out. In it you will find all the requirements for an API to be listed here. After you make your contribution, a sequence of automated tests will be run to expedite a review by one of the maintainers (@matheusfelipeog, @pawelborkar, @marekdano and @yannbertrand). Please stay tuned for test results. They will inform you as quickly as possible if your contribution has any problems. If the tests fail, your contribution has a problem and must be fixed in order to be merged. **Example of test failure:** ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50463866/135719841-d52fc5e0-610e-4255-a2ce-5d370b1987c2.png) See more information about the failure by clicking on the `Details` link **Example of test success:** ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50463866/135719851-8dd89cd1-cea4-47a9-a922-56ecace486c7.png) --- Learn more about Hacktoberfest 2021 at: https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/

issues.title: Migrate to a website
issues.body:
The time has come. We now have a lot of public JSON APIs.

It's a pain to search the ones we're interested in.

What about moving the data all of us have collected to a website with a powerful search engine? (take a look at https://twofactorauth.org/ for a good exemple)

comments_data.body: I was thinking more along the lines of http://justdelete.me
Love it! :smile:
Good idea, at the moment I don't have the time to do this though :/ how were you thinking of doing it, using Jekyll to render out all APIs from `_posts` data or something?

May I make a suggestion for moving this to a website?
Use [Elastic search](https://www.elastic.co/downloads/elasticsearch) as your search engine back-end.
I've been writing web apps in Ember and have been loving it.
A basic search web site shouldn't be too difficult to implement. I have a bit of time on my hands and would be willing to design a proof of concept if you are interested.
https://github.com/RyanNerd
I was thinking of migrating all the data to a json file and use it as a database. Do you think Jekyll would be an easier solution?

I'm not familiar with Jekyll so what I suggest below may be a bad idea, or a good idea:

I can provision a LAMP stack pretty quickly. I am using digitalocean.com as my host. For around $5/mo for a basic VM isn't a bad price. I use them to prototype web projects and I can scale my VM up easily if things get busy.
Writing the front-end will actually take me longer than setting up a back-end.
Let me know your thoughts.

Using a basic Digital Ocean VM is super easy to spin up and I've heard through the grapevine that sometimes DO will give you credit for a VM if the project is being hosted is popular enough/the README mentions the corresponding website is hosted by Digital Ocean (yay marketing!). Just some more food for thought to possibly make this task a bit financially easier.
DigitalOcean VM for a small droplet is around $5/mo. This is not a huge database and just needs a basic UI where this small VM would be just fine.
Yeah, DO is awesome. They very kindly sponsor two of my projects. @RyanNerd is right in that it only needs a small VM 👍
I've reached out to someone on the Sales team at DO to see if they'd be willing to sponsor this undertaking and provide us with a shiny new VM.

@davemachado if you are unable to get a VM for free from them let me know. I have a VM that I am using for testing purposes. For a small project like this I would be willing to share the VM slice (I use this VM very infrequently). So I'm paying $5/mo. just so that if I need to spin something up fast to test a deployment I can without a bunch of configuration. Right now it's like a boat in my garage during the winter (unused).

@RyanNerd thanks for the offer! I'm confident we will be able to work something out with DO, but your generosity is appreciated. 

My request has been "transferred" to the sponsorships team at DO so I'm anticipating hearing back from them soon! :)

My 2¢. There's no need for something this simple to need a backend. You can host it for free on something like github pages or [netlify](https://netlify.com) and just use a client side search library like [lunar.js](https://github.com/olivernn/lunr.js) to index a json file.
Update from DO: They are working on a proposal to be sent back soon. Sounds like a good sign!

Since we're still waiting to hear back from DO, I was interested for some input from folks regarding not having a server backend. For example, a project that I work with, [twofactorauth.org](https://twofactorauth.org/), uses github pages and Jekyll to serve the site ([github repo here](https://github.com/2factorauth/twofactorauth)), similar to what @marioharper was saying. I think using a system similar to twofactorauth.org would help streamline this process and make both the transition and maintenance of the list easier. This type of implementation would still allowing for a search component as well as cloud-based CI through [Travis](https://travis-ci.org/).

A project like this doesn't require anything as robust as a LAMP stack, or any web application stack for that matter. It would be easy enough to store the data in a json or sqllite file and use some simple javascript to display it. Github pages is more than suited for the task.

I'd suggest a simple `json` file with all the api data and then just render a static site with something like https://phenomic.io/ and toss on a free open source [netlify](https://www.netlify.com/) account

I don't really see an issue in having a simple readme tbh. I don't really think it needs an over baked website for a few links

@toddmotto

> On 4 Jan 2017, at 04:19, David Wells <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> I'd suggest a simple json file with all the api data and then just render a static site with something like https://phenomic.io/ and toss on a free open source netlify account
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
>

It seems like the ways in which a website would benefit this type of service would include things like advanced searching/filtering and being able to provide additional information or notes on a item-by-item basis- information that might not be applicable to be its own column for every single API. If the collective opinion is that these features aren't worth the effort to overhaul this README, then it sounds like website conversion should wait for another day.

Jekyll is a quick staticgen [staticgen.com to see more](//staticgen.com)

Which is great if you want to host it all from one or two git repositories, as the files are Static rather than using a backend, and replaced whenever a new build happens.

But it is also limited to only actions which can be commited by a CI agent like Travis or by JavaScript. Anything server-based is a no-no.

Personally I'm very much for the idea, as well as converting these table to JSON (which should be a sepearate issue.)

issues.title: Sponsoring this project
issues.body:
Hey all,

Firstly thanks for the great resource. I'm the new owner of [public-apis.io](https://public-apis.io) and the founder of [M3O](https://m3o.com) - a public api platform. I was wondering if there's any interest in adding sponsors to this repo and displaying logos/links to their site? We'd definitely be interested in adding M3O for such a thing.

Let me know if its of interest. I imagine many other API providers would love to do the same. It might enable some surplus cash for developers interested in doing more with the public apis stuff.

Cheers
Asim

comments_data.body:
Hi @asim,

Thanks for opening this issue and taking an interest in sponsoring the Public APIs, we really appreciate that. ❤️ 

Well, I had that idea in mind to talk to the other devs who maintain public apis. So, particularly, I think it's a great idea.

As you raised this discussion, I'll take it and take it to the other devs so we can see their opinion on it. As soon as I get an answer, I'll let you know here, ok?

@yannbertrand @pawelborkar @marekdano 

Guys, what do you think?
Community, what do you think? Feel free to give your opinion on this 😉

@asim, thanks for the offer!
I agree 😄
:wave: That would be greatly appreciated 👍

Sounds like its a unanimous yes to sponsorship. That's great to hear. Luckily github sponsors makes this stuff pretty straight forward, it's just a case for you to decide what kind of sponsor tiers you'd want and how to feature those sponsors.

A big THANKS for replying guys ❤️ 

@asim I will work on it. We collaborators will talk about how to organize this, the platform used to sponsor, the sponsor tiers and how to feature those sponsors.

This may take a few days, but we'll get these tasks done as soon as possible.

When everything is ready, I will inform you here and publicly in the repo.
Greetings devs, wanted to know if there was an update on adding sponsors and displaying their respective logos/links. Thanks in advance.
Still very much interested in sponsoring and getting our company logo from m3o.com in the project. Our goals are very much aligned and we want to help the cause.
How would I find sponsors to support this repo? Once I have that list, do I put their info in the documentation file?

Hi @LeoLivs and @asim ;)

Thanks for having and continuing your interest in sponsoring the Public APIs project. <3

Well, [as I said earlier](https://github.com/public-apis/public-apis/issues/1932#issuecomment-898970205), I would be responsible for this work, so I'll explain why we haven't started this yet:

The long wait time is basically motivated by the fact that it is extremely difficult to talk and get a response from the current owner of the public-apis organization. The current owners and their representative (@apilayer-admin) are extremely inactive in the organization and this repository. This makes it even more difficult.

We, currently active maintainers, would need to have access to organization and repository settings, which are currently only available to the owner, in order for us to be able to activate the sponsor button and make this feature public.

I've already considered using third-party platforms, which are normally used to sponsor open source projects as well, such as [open collective](https://opencollective.com/), and informing that we accept sponsorship on README.md (without the sponsor button). This would make it easier for us to start working with sponsorship.

But note that the current owner's lack of response affects not only the sponsorship functionality, but the project as a whole. As maintainers, we have some limitations, defined by GitHub, when we want to execute some of our ideas to improve the project for the community.

So to avoid any possible problems I'm waiting for a response from the owner so that we can improve the project with more control and safety for the community.

I really apologize for this delay, I am actively trying to resolve this without harming this amazing community. As soon as I get it, I will publicly inform you here in the issue and in the project.

Thanks for the detailed response! It's unfortunate you don't own the org. There's definitely alternative approaches but I think it's ok to wait for a response from the owner. I may ping again in January. Other potential options are just sponsor link to an Ethereum wallet 😀
@asim yes and I am even experienced in Blockchain and web3 stuff.
Continuing on with this discussion. Since it may not be possible to use github sponsors. Can we try something else? Like perhaps https://opencollective.com/
Looks good

Yes, you're right. We can try to use Open Collective

I'll take care of that and come back soon with more information. 🚀
Just an update: I'm awaiting approval from the Open Source Collective

The Open Source Collective fiscal host has approved the application of Public APIs:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50463866/152057719-8c237d4c-a159-465f-80a5-bb7f698c3857.png)

It is now possible to be a backer and sponsor of the project. See more information at: https://opencollective.com/public-apis

Soon, a section will be added to the `README.md` to inform everyone who visits the repository.

Able to make cross domain AJAX calls with client side JavaScript.

Is there anyway we can automate/assume a yes/no without manually checking them all?

@tublitzed, did you pick it up? Otherwise, I could take a stab at it.

Would be nice !

Ok, looks like I need to tackle this. For now, I'll add an empty space or a something.

For people who don't know what CORS is, we should add a "how to check" or similar to the contributing guide.

As far as my googling skills can tell me, the "easiest" way (besides conveniently specifying in the docs) would be to send a CORS request to an endpoint and see if it explodes or not. This could be done with postman or if you don't want to tediously hit them manually, maybe a small python/ruby script would help.

The problem here is for endpoints that require auth, hitting the endpoint might not be an option unless you feel like signing up for each and every service :) . To that, I'd offer trying to be sneaky and see if they have a demo endpoint you can hit.

issues.title: Jekyll site with search feature
issues.body:
Simple site with the ability to search.  I leaned heavily on http://2factorauth.org to integrate the search feature.  There's a pre-commit webhook to take the latest json file from /json and copy it to the /docs/_data directory.  That should keep the site in sync with the json generated off the README file. Once merged in, you'd have to change the settings to build from the /docs folder.

You can demo at http://ryankuhn.net/public-apis 

Before merging into the master branch, update the repo link in /docs/_includes/header.html.  Also, would recommend adding a link to the site on the README file.

issues.title: API key inconsistency
issues.body:
I noticed that Musixmatch API notes that an apikey query string required in the OAuth coulmn
As per my experiences APIs such as MovieDB, Wunderground, Open Weather Map, Yahoo Weather and maybe others require similar apikey query strings with the request.
I was wondering if this is a choice that has been made or an inconsistency in the list

Thanks for the wonderful compilation!

comments_data.body:
Hi @bkazi - If an API key is required it should say so. If there are any missing this is just a mistake. 

Now that we've merged a load, are there any you know require a key which isn't specified?

May we add a column to check if an api key is required (when not using OAuth)?

See #189
I think that issue has some validity - changing `oAuth` to `Auth` means the "No but an `apiKey` is required can be changed to just `apiKey`

Current solution:

| API | Description | OAuth | Link |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| API 1 | API 1 | Yes | Go! |
| API 2 | API 2 | No, but an `apiKey` is required | Go! |
| API 3 | API 3 | No | Go! |

Rename-oauth-column solution:

| API | Description | _Auth_ | Link |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| API 1 | API 1 | _`OAuth`_ | Go! |
| API 2 | API 2 | _`apiKey`_ | Go! |
| API 3 | API 3 | No | Go! |

Add-a-column solution:

| API | Description | _Auth_ | OAuth | Link |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| API 1 | API 1 | _Yes_ | Yes | Go! |
| API 2 | API 2 | _Yes_ | No | Go! |
| API 3 | API 3 | _No_ | No | Go! |

I agree with @mikestreety, the second solution seems to be the neatest. What do think of it?
Hmm, if we're to generate JSON from this data, then we want it to be as verbose as possible, right?
I don't think we should let potential JSON-ification get in the way of readability? We could head down route two and then route three for the JSON and compile it into a route 2 looking table?

Because this list of API's is publicly supported, I think the renaming the OAuth column to just Auth adds the opportunity to add a bit more detail into the method of authorization instead of just a blunt Yes/No. I would recommend this in hopes of keeping a consistent naming scheme so that we don't end up having variations of one type of Auth (apikey, ApiKey, Key, APIKEY, etc).

We could add a "contributing" guide and include a list of existing ones so that several variations don't occur.

Are we looking to know that just an API Key is required? Is there any reason it's written `apiKey`? I assume that's the actual parameter name - but it seems to have malformed into a standard phrase
To solve the issue of having multiple naming schemes for the same auth type, perhaps adding a table at the top of the README to explain the different choices for Auth would be best suited.
@mikestreety beat me to it.... 👍
There is one PR outstanding. Once merged I say let's go for this 👍

I just opened a PR (#252) that adds a contributing guide to the project. I think it pretty much outlines what we are looking for in a submission (including the apiKey inconsistency), but if anyone has changes they'd like to propose, I'd be more than happy to add them in. :)
This has also been resolved in the same PR :smile: Once merged we can finally get rid of this issue!
Closing this as it is now resolved

issues.title: Add Link Verification through CI
issues.body: Speaking to Issue #11 , I think it is important to keep a running check on all existing links to make sure at a bare minimum that there is still some website to link to, rather than it just being a dead link taking space up on the page. Currently it seems the only way we can tell if a service has died is if someone tries to use it and the link is dead or the user is connected to the service in some way - either way, it doesn't look too good from a maintaining standpoint. It seems like this tool will do the job for us, and it opens the door for any other schweet CI-checking fun in the future!

issues.title: Bring JSON generation into master branch
issues.body: Continuing where PR #362 left off.

comments_data.body:
@yannbertrand thanks for the review! I updated `md2json` accordingly, so it now sets auth to null if no auth is needed and HTTPS support is set to boolean values. I think that silly `if (line) { }` statement was supposed to be a placeholder for something once upon a time, but it's obviously not needed anymore.

I also updated the stock json files to reflect the new format. Let me know what y'all think!

I do agree with @kuhnrl30 - I personally think categories should be an array on each item. When rendered out, we can display as they currently are (then that means a link can appear in many categories, but only have one source of truth).

If you wanted to go down the "programming" route, each category could have an ID, to stop typos and very similar categories appearing.

e.g.

```
{
	"Categories": [
		1: "Animals",
		2: "Anime"
	],
	"APIs": [
		{
			"API": "AniList", 
			"Auth": "`OAuth`", 
			"Description": "AniList Anime", 
			"HTTPS": "No", 
			"Link": "http://anilist-api.readthedocs.io/en/latest/",
			"Categories": [1, 2]
		}
	]
}
```

I should clarify my opinion - for a website with searching capability, I think categories make complete sense, since the information can easily be filtered for viewing without being overwhelming. However, the list of entries currently stands as one big README, which means we'd need duplicate listings in the one file. That would also mean that any updates to an entry (i.e. new auth requirements) would need to hit all instances of the entry in the file. I agree with @mikestreety 's point of having one source of truth, but with the current layout of the README, I don't see how that's going to be possible for sane maintenance.

[twofactorauth](https://github.com/2factorauth/twofactorauth/tree/master/_data) is a nice project that many people base these types of "list websites" off of, and they use YAML files for categories to render each independently of each other, only coming together in the final rendering. Without trying to overcomplicate our project here, I think we would need to adopt a variation of the separate files system in order to reduce overall maintenance of entries without duplication of effort.

More food for thought :)

Do we even need the README to be a source of truth?  Can we convert to JSON once and then use that as the source going forward?  The README could be reduced to a link to the site for easy reading.  

You can use json or yaml in jekyll site. We've already started with json so I'd suggest we stay with it.

This project has quite a large footprint in terms of daily GitHub traffic, so we need to proceed with caution and respect for the visitors here - baby steps are key for smooth transitions. The README is the key component to the overall use of the project right now. After incorporating the JSON into the repo, I think a discussion of possibly updating the source of truth to be the JSON generating the Markdown tables can be warranted, but the first step is to bring this new structure into the fold.
I am going to start taking this in a slightly different direction - will have a new PR posted soon.

Not sure why I closed this...but anyways, after playing with this a bit, It's becoming clear how much of a nightmare for maintenance using category IDs would be. For example, if someone wants to create a new category, they'll have to find the last known ID number used, which is going to be out of order (i.e. not at the end of the list) depending on if the categories are kept in alphabetical order. Currently, users sometimes have a hard time putting their new entries in alphabetical order, and this change in workflow would only exacerbate it.

I would like to move ahead with the originally proposed JSON that reflects the current format of the README, which is the source of truth for the entire project. From there, I think separate conversations can be started regarding any thoughts for migrating the source of truth from the README to the JSON, website, etc, which could then include motivation to change the format of the JSON, and therefore the README.

However, the goal of the feature outlined in this PR is to provide an easy-to-code-with format of the project. Since the project is based on the category-sorted markdown tables in the README, I'm standing by my original proposal as both "good enough for now" and to inspire motivation to start those separate conversations mentioned above.

As always, thoughts are welcome.

issues.title: Inactive PRs must be closed and their APIs added
issues.body:
There are many inactive PRs that have already been revised and with their APIs according to our addition criteria. These PRs are just waiting for some correction that was requested by one of the maintainers, and as they are inactive PRs, they will likely not be done.

Inactive PRs must be closed and their APIs added if they still meet our criteria.

Maintainers can add the APIs of these PRs in their respective sections directly on the master branch (since they have already been reviewed previously).

Contributors can open new PRs to add APIs of inactive PR.

Consider as inactive PR those that have no reply from their creator for more than 1 month.

To facilitate tracking, please mark the inactive PR in the new PR.

issues.title: Added & improved Steam API
issues.body:
So, Valve (creator of Steam) has an official wiki about their Steam Web API, but it's limited and quite outdated. 
There is a community-equivalent doc site, which is way better (has functionality, more supported endpoints, updated, etc.). 
I think it's good to link both. 
Then, there is also web API steam uses internally, which includes many interesting and useful endpoints as well.
These endpoints do not require an API key and are documented in a different repo.

`^\| (.*?) \| (.*) \| \[Go!\]\((.*)\) \|$`, with this replacement: `| [$1]($3) | $2 |`

Hey guys, in order to help @jezmck not have to deal with painful merge conflict resolutions on this PR, I used [this gist](https://gist.github.com/davemachado/fb3b20642f807543730ec5505996760c) to move the links and this is merged in at e2b66cea263d77107000855ce66fb3554922dd02 . issues.title: Help Required: API not documented
issues.body:
I use these few APIs for world political data analysis provided by Lowy Institute, Australia

+ `https://power.lowyinstitute.org/data/2020.json`
+ `https://power.lowyinstitute.org/countries.json`
+ `https://power.lowyinstitute.org/world.json`
+ `https://power.lowyinstitute.org/network-power.json`

Their reports and data are also used IMF and other UN foundations.
But they don't have proper documentation so i can't add one direct link in repo. Please suggest me what should i do?

comments_data.body: (Expecting replies since 1931.)

@0x0is1 As stated in the contribution guide, it's necessary for the API to have official documentation in order to be added to the list. And as this API doesn't meet this requirement, unfortunately, it's not possible to add it.
That's quite sad😓 but okay..!

> That's quite sad😓 but okay..!

@0x0is1 I thought of something. 🤔

You can create a repository here on github and create unofficial documentation for this API. So I can accept for listing.

You should document and explain what each of these endpoints is for so others can easily use them.

What do you think?

Some examples you can follow:

- https://github.com/btcid/indodax-official-api-docs/blob/master/Public-RestAPI.md
- https://github.com/thundercomb/poetrydb#readme
- https://github.com/CrossRef/rest-api-doc
Thanks for the amazing suggestion. Working on it. :)
Okay, I'll be waiting. Request my review when you're done, please. ;)
Resolved in #2982.
